MITOCHONDRIA

The primary function of mitochondria is to generate energy in the form of ATP and thus they are termed as powerhouses of the eukaryotic cells. Mitochondria have its own genetic system and approximately 1% of the mitochondrial proteins are synthesized by the mitochondrial genome.

With a circular genome having 37 genes that encode 13 proteins, 22 tRNAs and 2 rRNAs it is not only having a central role in energy conversion, but also in the multiple metabolic and signaling pathways with crucial roles in amino acids and lipids metabolism and biosynthesis of heme and iron sulphur clusters.

APPROACH

The role of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) mutations has been well understood for its role in the cause of inherited diseases. A considerable progress has also been achieved in the identification of the mtDNA mutations in both ageing and cancer. Mitochondrial diseases can be caused not only by the mutations and misregulations of proteins coded by mtDNA but also by those encoded in the nuclear encoded mitochondrial genes or both.

Unique approach which takes a systems biology approach to study mitochondria and its functions as a whole. Mutation and expression data are mapped on to the mitochondrial model developed from combining known functions of mitochondria at the protein protein interactions level. This will provide sufficient understanding of not only the consequence of a affected gene/protein from a single function but across functions.
